segments.text: Male homosexuals have equal rights.
The Supreme Court in Bowers v. Hardwick in 1986 refused to extend the whole notion of the right of privacy to homosexual activity, upholding a state law from Georgia, which made it a crime.
for people to engage in sexual relations with others of the same sex.
And not all states have such laws.
Texas does not.
In fact, I think the majority of states no longer do.
But they're being told they can't enforce them.
Homosexuals face discrimination in child custody.
women have lost custody of their children because they were lesbians.
Now, in at least 90% of divorces, women retain custody of the kids.
There just are not enough male homosexuals who actively sought custody to tell whether they're being discriminated against.
But there was at least one case, for example, where a man who...

had been divorced, was gay, and had visitation rights, was forbidden to take his children to the gay church he attended, even though that would seem to be in his First Amendment religious rights, and was forbidden to let them have any association with his gay male friends, as if they were going to rape his son, which is ridiculous.
Homosexuals face discrimination in the workplace, and certainly that has not ever been addressed by federal laws.
One of the cruelest forms of discrimination is what arises from the fact that there is no state anywhere in this country in which homosexuals may marry.
And that means that unless you have ordinances or laws as we do now in San Francisco,
If you are a homosexual living with your mother,
your lover cannot be a beneficiary of your health insurance.
Now, you can, with a life insurance policy, usually you can name whomever you wish as a beneficiary.

But, for example, if, as often happens, two men, say, are living together, and one of them is employed full-time and the other one is a student and doesn't have good health insurance, the student cannot
become, I mean, the employed man cannot buy a family insurance and let his lover be the beneficiary.
Whereas if a couple are married and one of them is working and the other is a student, there's no problem at all.
You very frequently have a situation if one partner dies,
and dies without a will, who of course the family inherits and may very well push the lover out of the home in which they've been living.
That can be remedied by will.
There is a tragic case in Minnesota, although it's been resolved very well,
fairly well now after a very long wait, but a couple, Karen Thompson and Sharon Kowalski were living together.
And Sharon was in a bad automobile accident and in a coma.
And her father went to court and got named her guardian.
He forbade Thompson from seeing her, and he put his daughter in a nursing home and essentially let her walk for three and a half years.
Not only couldn't she see her lover, she didn't even have rehabilitation, and all this precious time was simply lost.
And now, a year ago, Thompson won the right to go to see her, and they were able to communicate.
She cannot speak, but she does use a computer.
Kowalski rather.

Kowalski was able to communicate that she wanted to stay with Karen and then now the father has withdrawn his guardian and I think either Thompson is guardian or they've decided that Kowalski is confident to manage her own affairs.
But that kind of thing has happened a lot.
With AIDS, very frequently what has happened is that a man will get sick and his family
essentially will take over and will treat him very, very badly because in some anti-gay families the attitude has been, you brought this on yourself, and they won't let the lovers see the man.
These are things that people can take care of by drawing up wills, by drawing up legalized documents of what they want to happen, but of course most people don't do that.
Homosexuals are, in many, many respects, second classes.
They simply do not have the rights that heterosexuals, especially married heterosexuals, do as a matter of course.
I'll let you do a little speculating on homosexual rights.
What do you think legislatively will happen, and what do you think the courts will do about this?
Oh, I think the courts will be uniform.
Well, the federal courts, thanks to Reagan, will be hostile for a long, long time.
Within states, it varies.
You know, the only person really to look into homosexual voting strength was Mondale.
when he got the Democratic nomination in 1984.
And his people believe that there is in this country a core of about
400 million voters who will define themselves primarily as homosexuals and who will vote as a bloc.
Now, most experts, and this is really since the dawn of civilization, believe that the incidence of homosexuality in any society
is relatively constant, that it's about 10%.
People are just born that way.
And if that's true, of course, we don't have 4 million homosexuals.
We have 25 million.
But he was talking about 4 million that would vote that way.
Now, on a national level, I mean, that's really significant.
If it's scattered,
since many, many homosexuals still cannot identify themselves as such, you don't have that much voting strength.
Now obviously in places like San Francisco you do, in New York City, but even in New York City it took them more than 10 years to get a gay rights ordinance passed.
I think that's going to be a very slow process.
I hope eventually
We're going to be at a place where homosexuals will have fully equal rights and will be able to marry, but that's going to be a slow one.
Let's talk about your latest paper, or one of your latest papers, The Limits of Constitutional Doctrine in Women's Rights.
That is a paper that has now been submitted for publication.
I'm waiting to hear about it, and I delivered it at the Scott Press in Sweden I talked about.
And basically I was looking at a very interesting phenomenon, which is that if you look at the cases since 1971 when the Supreme Court began

Using the Equal Protection Clause to recognize women's rights, you find that the majority of, not the majority of successful plaintiffs, but the majority of plaintiffs and the most recent plaintiffs have been men, and that the primary
beneficiaries of these new cases have been men, not women.
And you begin asking yourself, why?
And I think I came up with something very interesting, because the way that the court, well, we saw it in the Baki case.
The court doesn't talk about oppression, inequality, subjection, inferiority.
The court talks about discrimination.
Its language is neutral.
And that language is a lot of help to a man who has to pay alimony.
in a state where only men have to do that.
But if you have a woman who's trying to make a claim about divorce, for example, there's no question it doesn't relate very well into the terms that are set by the judges.
And I look into the history of some of that.
It's not that the justices sit down and say, OK, we're men.
How can we develop law for men?
It's the neutral concepts they have developed
serve the status quo, whether it's male, whether it's white, whether it's upper class or bourgeois, whatever it is.
And that constitutional language just does not work very well to

satisfy women's aims this is going to be probably part of a book that i'm doing on what is called feminist jurisprudence and that's really a growing field in the discipline looking at law from the point of view not of men but correct me if i'm wrong there's been probably three doctrines used in in this uh
constitutional doctrines used for sexuality cases.
What do you mean?
Up to 71, a certain doctrine was used.
Through the 70s, we had a doctrine, then it changed.
Oh, well, sort of.
Okay, you're talking about sex discrimination.
Up to 71...
It was basically a blank check.
Sex discrimination was okay if the states wanted to do it.
After 1971, they kind of, between 71 and 76, they kind of toyed with it.
Well, for a while, you had four justices who thought you should treat sex as a suspect by the way you treat race discrimination.
That never got a majority of the court.
And then in 76, they came out with the Intermediate Standard in favor of scoring.
that sex discrimination had to bear a substantial relationship to an important governmental objective.
And that's essentially where we are now.
So it wasn't really three doctrines.
It was two and a half, because they never actually decided to make sex a subject classification.
So you said that men are benefiting right now from the constitutional doctrine.
How about there are benefits from cultural reasons like, I mean, the economics, etc.?
Well, sure.
One of the things that I thought about was, hey, maybe men benefit because men just consume more often, go to court more often than women.
Well, there are a few studies of litigation.
Nobody asked that question.
So I devised a very clumsy and very crude measure.
My graduate assistant and I just went through the court cases and the applications for cert and counted names.
And we left out the criminal cases because those are going to be all male.
We left out the corporations because we knew the CEOs would be nearly all male.
And we just looked at cases where we could identify a plaintiff and we found they were all male.
The lowest ratio we got was 2 to 1.
The highest was infinity because there was one set in which none of the plaintiffs were women.
And I said, you know, I'm still waiting to see what's said about this now that I've sent it out for review, because this is crude, and I know it's crude.
But it really does look at, okay, when the Supreme Court is meeting to decide what it's going to grant concern on, that most of the cases there are bought by males anyway.
So, yes, I think there is an economic reason.
A lot of studies have said litigation benefits the haves, not the have-nots.
It takes money, it takes time, it takes resources to bring a case.
You've got to get a lawyer.
Well, most obviously, that means you've got to pay a lawyer.

Even if through some miracle you get a lawyer who will take the case on a contingency fee basis, which means that he or she expects to win, if you bring any kind of suit, I assure you, you will do a lot of the work yourself.
It takes money and time.
In the 50s, the NAACP helped out the black movement by organizing and getting money together and having lawyers to do that.
What is NOW doing?
Now does have a legal defense in education fund.
And they do help out some people.
Now does not have an awful lot of money, at least for those purposes.

But also another, you know, when I talk, when I said that about claims generally, I was not talking about, you know, when I say women bring suits to women, I was not saying they bring them more often in sex discrimination.
I was saying they bring them, period.
Right.
So only a very small fraction of the cases brought before the court have to do with sex discrimination.
And there's a lot of disagreement among feminists about, hey, are the courts the best place to look?
Not right now they're not.
I mean, when somebody has a claim, the best thing to do is to resolve it.
between the two parties.
The easiest and the cheapest thing is a conference between two lawyers.
But of course now, the corporation that's being sued or the employer, it basically may say to the woman and her lawyer, screw you.
I'm going to court.
I may win.
That's the difficulty.
You had an interesting sentence in the paper about psychological reasons that men litigate more.
Oh, yeah.
Are they more...
Okay, that's an old joke about... Bertrand Russell, the philosopher, wrote a little thing about how you conjugate irregular verbs.
First person, I am firm.
Second person, you are obstinate.
Third person,
He's pig-headed.
Well, you know, maybe men are more assertive than women.
Who knows?
Does that mean they're more firm, more obstinate, or more pig-headed?
Well, I leave that to the reader.
But, of course, it's also maybe men are just kicked around more than women.
But whichever of these are true, we really don't need to resolve it.
Well, let's talk about what movement may go.
Where does it want to go?
What does it want to do now?
Oh, boy.
The movement...
is not monolithic.

There is this division basically between people like Schwartz and Hewlett, the ones who want to emphasize accommodating women's role in the family and those who want to question the role in the family.
But I think, however, even guaranteeing that, there are some things that everybody's agreed on.
I think all feminists,
recognize the need for child care.
Whether you're a mommy tracker or not, whether you believe that women have to choose one or the other, you are likely to believe that there need to be better maternity leaves.
I mean, the average woman would look at six weeks
You don't recover physically, the baby isn't sleeping through the night, you haven't established a feeding schedule, you go back to work and you're exhausted.
And you need also parenting leaves for both men and women.
Women, whether they're mothers or not, whether their family is more important to them than their job or not, women need an end to sexual harassment.
They need equal opportunity.
They don't really clearly have it, although we're getting toward that.
Most feminists are agreed that the right to choose
to continue or terminate pregnancy is a necessity.
Now, there's a group that calls itself Feminists for Life, and there was an article about them being equal today.
I basically think, I don't think that if you take that viewpoint, you can be a feminist, because those women always end up arguing, well, women have a special responsibility towards children.
And I don't think that if you believe that women and men are equal, you can believe that women come with an extra load of responsibilities that men have.
I don't think that's equality.
Most feminists are united on that issue that reproductive choice is a necessity.
But that, of course, is two-sided in European countries.
mother who has custody of a child gets a subsidy from the state.
We're a long way from having that, and I wouldn't say that the movement saw it as a goal, but it is one way that responsibilities toward children could be made easier.
There are lots of ways that we need to aid and help women with children.
Well, we've kind of established that the courts aren't going to be one of the methods used by the movement so legislatively.
Well, they're not going to be used as much.
State courts will be.
Who's going to be doing this?
Who's going to lead this movement?
Who's going to be its core?
Some people?
New people?
I think that you'll begin attracting new people.

A lot of the people, certainly one of the leading feminists, Faye Waddleton of Planned Parenthood, who was speaking in Austin the other day, the women political officials that are elected are going to be very important.
We have, I think, 27 to 28 members of Congress.
We have three women governors.
Some of us are hoping there'll be four pretty soon.
There are women judges, especially in the state courts.
it's very hard to know who the leaders of the movement are going to be in 20 years or in 10 years.
But there will be people.
In fact, maybe some feminists would tell you, hey, this concentration on leaders is a bad thing.
Because that's really hierarchical.
You know, it was funny.
Last night I went to a NOW meeting, and I was a little late.
And when I walked in, everybody said, Judy, you've got to write a letter to the Eagle about that story about the Ann Richards thing.
And I said, hey, wait a minute.
I wrote the last letter.
but you're so good at it.
Hey, come on.
You can't have one or two people grabbing all the publicity.
Somebody else is going to write the letter.
And I think that basically that's a better style of activity than the leadership.
I hope that the women's movement will never have
the equivalent of a Martin Luther King or a Mark Malcolm X. I mean, the black movement needed both of those people.
Or a Jesse Jackson.
Well, I don't know.
We're obviously going to have the first woman candidate for president.
Maybe it'll be Pat Schroeder, who wrote about it last time.
And she's probably going to lose, the same way Jackson has.
I think that King and Malcolm were essential to the black movement, don't get me wrong, but I am not sure the feminist movement has the same kind of keys.
What are you going to do?
I'm going to keep on being scholar first and activist second.
I've got plans for this world to book on.
Women in the Law, which is going to be an undergraduate text, should be out in the fall of 1990.
And I'm going to write this feminist shirt for this thing.
And I probably will continue to be active in feminist things in Brazos Valley.
I mean, this is the smallest community I've ever lived in.
And essentially, you know, I'm used to if you're in Chicago or Los Angeles or Albany, you know, there's going to be a demonstration.
There's usually a sign that says, bus will be leaving such and such a place at such and such a time.
Call this number to make a reservation.
The cost is $10.
What I have learned is that in
Brazos County, if I don't do it, it doesn't get done.
There are a few of us, and you know, we had to rent a van and all this stuff.
And basically the nitty-gritty stuff has to be done by a few individuals.
So probably I'll continue to be more prominent than I was ever before, simply because there are fewer of us here.
Well, what about your textbook?
Okay, that may be using that, most of it, because there's only one chapter that needs to be written.
As a, you know, I'm going to send it to Kinko's and use it for my Women in the Law course this coming spring.
I used part of it last time.
It's not designed as a casebook.
I have a casebook there.
It's really designed as a general treatment of the subject of women in the law, both for students and for a general audience.
is not original research.
It's the only textbook of its kind so far, and the publisher assures me that they already have advance orders for it.
So, of course, I'll probably end up revising it every year, but anyway, that's what happens when you write a text.
When I was approached with that, I was at Cal Poly, California State Polytechnic University, Pomona, which has a horrendous teaching load, and I didn't think I would ever get any real research done.
And I thought, why don't you just do this?
It's the kind of thing you can do.
without having to devote some really heavy thinking to it, and you might even get it done.
So go ahead, and I did, and then I moved here, and I've got a lot more time to do research.
Well, let's talk about A&M a little bit then.
Okay, this is my second year here.
This is a wonderful department to be in.
very diverse, very bright, very hardworking, active, productive people.
One of the things I could improve about the university was the law collection of the library, but it is a good place to work.
The community is a small town, southern community, and that's very hard for a New Englander to live in.
It's a long way from Cambridge.
It's an interesting kind of adjustment.
Does it seem like it's behind the times a little bit?
Yes.
I'll give an example.
I'm on the Women's Studies Program Review Committee, and we had a retreat last spring, and we were talking about the same issue, basically, the relational feminism, mommy track, family issue.
And somebody said, one of the women faculty in the College of Liberal Arts said, well, the movement can even include lesbians.
And I had to bite my tongue.
I just wanted to hear it, and say, the lesbians in Berkeley, Cambridge,
Madison and Iowa City will really be very glad.
It is just so totally beyond the time.
That is not an issue.
There's a lag time for things, like the black movement.
They got legal rights.
The movement was able to get legal rights through the courts, through legislation.
And then, socially, it hasn't turned.
What about this woman's view?
There is an extent to which I am a Marxist.
I accept the idea that there are economic classes in society, one of which exploits the other.
Blacks, when there are workers, that's when they're lucky.
Women are workers and wives.
are owners, and I mean owners of means of production, they're not any longer owners of good means.
Of course there's going to be a lag between the achievement of equal rights and full economic equality.
The reason that most groups need equal rights is that they're economically unequal, and the reason that most groups are economically unequal is because they are exploited.
The labor of blacks as slaves, as sharecroppers, as workers is exploited.
The labor of women as unpaid house workers, as maids, as secretaries, as nurses, as school teachers has been exploited.
Now, that's not true of all disadvantaged groups.
The disabled are not exploited systematically, although certainly many of them, you know,
You can work for Goodwill Industries if you're blind making light bulbs for 60 cents an hour.
I mean, come on.
But it's not a systematic economic exploitation.
To some extent, the disabled are cut out of the exploitation situation at all.
So are Native Americans.
I mean, they've been encouraged.
The tape player messed up.
I came back the next day and continued the interview.
We're on the same question.
I'll let her close up.
She's saying that this is true of the oppressed groups, of all oppressed groups.
There'll still be a little bit of a break, but there's about 15 more minutes of interview.
Many oppressed groups, that this oppression is economically feasible, and that is one reason that it continues.
Another reason is that even when laws change, people do not necessarily think of doing anything different than what they have been doing.
Most of the women my age, in the 40s and even in the 30s, really believe, that's age, not decade, of the century, really were encouraged to think
in terms of such female occupations as being teachers, social workers, librarians.
If you were working class, you were often
encouraged to think of yourself as a nurse or a secretary.
These are all clerical workers.
These are all poorly paid, poorly rewarded, traditionally female professions.
And to the extent that women go into those, whether they go into them voluntarily or not, they are
really going into exploited jobs and things are not going to change very much.
This is not only because they choose them, this is because they never really have the opportunity to choose anything else.
Certainly, law cannot immediately change the behavior either of people who have been exploited or the behavior of people who have been doing the exploiting.
Men are going to continue to treat women in certain ways, whites to treat blacks in certain ways, and so on.
So it is very hard to affect permanent social change, and it's a long, long struggle to do that.
One interesting thing, you know, there's a great, great deal of debate
within social science professions as to whether blacks are oppressed by racism or that they are oppressed by factors within their own behavior.
And the example always given is the family structure.
You know that there are a lot of more black women than white women have jobs.
children beginning at age 15 and don't get married and so on.
It's suggested that the real problem is not racism, it's that so many people live in this way which virtually cuts them out of any kind of economic advancement.
But of course the question has to be asked why anyone should be expected to conform their family
structure to the white middle class norm.
You know, essentially people may not be so much disadvantaged for being black as disadvantaged for a different kind of family structure, a different kind of choices which seem quite natural.
And yes, it would be much better if black teenagers didn't have babies, but on the other hand, poverty is not a natural consequence of
having a family which is headed by a young female single parent.
It is a socially imposed consequence.
I'm going to let you wrap this interview up on any point you'd like to make and just add anything you feel like you'd like to add.
Actually, I think really this is about it.
I got a lot said that day.
I thought that that thing had really gone on the blink a lot earlier than it had.
No, you got most of it.
I really think there was only a minute or two that we didn't get.
That's right.
So I think really that's about it.
We can wind that up.
Thank you.
Okay, now they're working.
Come on, record something.
Let me hear what you got to say.
